text: (upbeat music)
- Welcome to "Conversations with Leaders."
My name is Jake Burns.
I'm an Enterprise Strategist with AWS.
Today I'm joined by Brandon Pulsipher

who's the Vice President of
Cloud Operations at Adobe.
Brandon, welcome.
- Thanks, good to be here.

- So can you start off, tell
us a little bit about yourself,
your background and what you do at Adobe?
- Yeah, I've been at Adobe,

I came about 12 years
ago through acquisition.
Spent 10 years before that
with a startup in the digital marketing
and kind of digital transformation space.

And now I've spent the
last 10 years helping Adobe
along this cloud journey as we've expanded
and just taken that journey together

with both the solutions that
Adobe purchased and acquired

as well as the transition
of the Creative Cloud
that most people are familiar with.

- And so what does Cloud
Operations at Adobe do?

- Yeah, it's a, I think,
intentionally broad term

so that we can put
whatever we want in there,
but focus on the cloud infrastructure,

whatever sort of your
interpretation of cloud is.

If that's internal/external,
kind of public/private,
all of the end-to-end infrastructure,
however we deliver that,

focus on the cloud
spend, cloud efficiency,
and kind of cloud maturity,

and just kind of helping the
business continue to adopt

and use the modern technologies
in a way that adds value.
- I understand that at Adobe

you've tried a few different
organizational models
and models for IT.
How do you know a model's working,
and how do you react quickly

when you find out that
things aren't working?
- Yeah, I think this kind of concept

of agile, and kind of
the engineering world
making its way to IT

has been a really fun kind
of merger of mindsets to see,
and see the IT industry embrace that.

And I'd say that's part
of what we've been through
in this cloud journey where operations
and engineering really come together.

And so we've had to charter
a little bit of our own path
through that kind of DevOps SRE.
What does that mean?
How do we get there?
How do we move from the sysadmin world

to this new approach of
Infrastructure as Code.
And we've been through quite a few

organizational adjustments
and changes to get there.

And I think, for me, three
or four organizations

and organizational names over
last three or four years,

but folks have embraced it,
and, I think, are excited
and energized by new ways of doing things.
And so it's been an exciting transition.

- So Brandon, a big focus for
you has been cloud efficiency.
I'm curious, how do you track that?

And maybe we could start off,
what is cloud efficiency?

- Yeah, I think that is
an important question
because I think it's one of these things
we're still kind of defining.
There's not a sort of industry definition

or a set of standards that
necessarily define that.

So I think it a little bit
has to be defined individually
by each company or organization,
and what their objectives are, but I think

it's what's important
in terms of efficiency,

how do we make sure
we're using every dollar
the best way in creating value?

Obviously, we all wanna
drive every dollar we can
into kind of innovation and creativity
and value for our customers.

And so if we're spending extra
dollars on infrastructure,
then we're not able to do that.
So I think it's just about making sure

we have the right balance
in that investment.

- Well, coming from Amazon,
I really love that answer.
(laughs) every dollar you're not spending
on customers is not efficient, you know.
That's a good way to look at it.
Do you think there's a trade-off
between efficiency and agility?
- I don't think there has to be.

I think actually they
fit really well together.

I think agility, the ability
to be elastic and scale up.

And I think a lot of companies
scale up really well,

'cause we are forced
into building for that,
from an IT and an engineering aspect,

but the same forcing
function doesn't exist

to have to scale down, and
the other side of agility.
But I think there's a lot of value there
that can be derived.
They don't have to be competitive.

Great agility and the
ability to be elastic
and spin up and spin down
can create a great customer experience
and drive better efficiency.

So it doesn't have to be sort
of choose one or the other.

There's a sort of two-for
benefit you can get.
- Yeah, that's a great point.
It's something that I always talk about.
We love to talk about scaling up,

but we don't talk about
scaling down often enough.
And it's kind of like scaling down
is too boring to talk about.

It's like cost savings
and eliminating waste.

But actually I think if you
take a more long-term view,
and I wonder if you agree with this,

just having that ability
to shut things off
and stop paying for them,

and having the ability
to scale things down

tends to make organizations
bolder in what they try
and what they experiment with
because the cost of failure is much less.

So it actually has kind
of an exciting benefit

that probably stems from
that ability to scale down.
- Yeah. I completely agree.
I think that's true.

And I think the more
that we can drive value

and understand agility and
how do we prevent failure,
but how do we learn from failure?

'Cause, inevitably, in any
kind of agile approach,
there's gonna be some degree of failure.

And so we have to understand
and acknowledge that as a risk

and just make sure we
learn from it and adapt.
Failure is not a problem.

The same failure again
and again is a problem.
- Yeah. I would go so far as to say

if you're not failing, at
least some of the time,
you're probably not trying hard enough.
- Yeah, I think that's true.
And the challenge we haven't acknowledged

in this industry is how
do we embrace the ability
to be agile and experience that failure,

but abstract our customers
from being impacted by that?
- Right, right. Exactly.

So a good failure would be
one where it's something
where your customers aren't impacted,
but you're learning,
and you're not making that same mistake
over and over again, obviously.
And a bad failure would be one
where it does impact customers.

And obviously, we don't wanna
have those kind of failures.
So the correct strategy, or good strategy,

would be one where we're
allowing ourselves to fail
but not have it impact our end customers.
- Yeah, I completely agree.
I think that's the end goal we all have.

- So Brandon, one of
the things that comes up
when we engage with executives

going through transformations
is this question,

does it have to be a
top-down led transformation
or can it start from the middle?
Can it grow organically from the bottom?
I'm wondering how did this transformation
come about at Adobe?

And what are your thoughts
on how to initiate one?
- Yeah, I probably....

I don't think it has
to come from top down,
and often, probably...

Well, maybe sometimes
there's a vision statement
of, hey, we need to change.
Certainly the how we get there
often comes from the people
who are sort of on the front lines,
and they have the best insight often.

And so I think, if we make
these transformations at least
without getting the input,
and having that dialogue with the teams,
I think that'd be a miss
because there's so much we can learn.

So I think it should be
a combination of both.

And that said, I think that's
when it works really well,

when we've gone through
some of our transformation.
I think we struggled a little bit

with this kind of DevOps mindset
transformation for a while,

and I think for us that
secret sauce was that balance

of kind of frontline managers
and executive sponsorship
and leaders that were committed.
And when we sat down every week

with kind of these frontline
set of managers and directors

and we shared the stories
and we talked about the need,

and we didn't let up, we did
that for month after month.

And people started to
see that this is real
and we're serious about it.
And you saw it sort of come together
throughout the organization.

It wasn't being pushed
from the bottom as an idea
that people felt is not going anywhere.
It wasn't some top-down mandate.
It really was this sort of combination
of bringing the right things together.
- Interesting, so it sounds like

there was some planning
involved before you got started.
- Yeah, I think planning,

and, I think, attempts
and failed attempts.
We probably started early on
with that sort of top-down mandate,
like, hey, we need to move faster
to this kind of DevOps mindset
and Infrastructure as Code.
And that sounded really good,

but not every network administrator
or system administrator
is ready to start writing code.
And so I think we certainly had to invest
in the skill side of that,
and both invest in the people we had
and supplementing that as we hired
with, maybe we hire a software developer
and not a sort of infrastructure person.
And so how do we sort of...
Creating that mix, I think, was valuable,
but yeah, it took some time
and it definitely has been a journey.
- So any last advice?
I mean, there's a lot of people out there

who are still, believe
it or not, starting out
on their transformation journey,
or starting out with the cloud.
For those that are just starting out,
and are trying to lead a change,

any kind of general advice
that you would give?

- I think, just be willing
to try new things out.
I think, again, another sort of,
I think, leadership concept or quality

that I think we're coming
around to is this vulnerability.

And so being willing to
be a little bit vulnerable

and maybe it's have an
uncomfortable conversation
to say I think we need to make a change.
What's the value this is gonna create?
And then step forward and try it out,

and then be willing to say,
hey, it worked or it didn't.

And then I think finding
the right partners

to help you along the way
is an important aspect.
We don't have to go this alone.

Fortunately, while there's
still a lot of folks
maybe early in the journey,

there's a lot that we
can learn from others
that have gone before us in a lot of ways.
- I agree. I agree.
There's never been a better time

to be doing a cloud
migration or transformation

just because we have so many
great examples nowadays,
unlike a few years ago, right?
A very short few years ago.

Nowadays we have so many
great examples of what works.
Some examples of what doesn't work.

And so we're not going into
the unknown anymore, right?
So learn from those who've done it before.

- Yeah, yeah, I think that's
an absolutely valuable concept.

And again, maybe not every
element of that applies,
but I think that's one of the things
we see value in with AWS

is sometimes we're still
migrating workloads to the cloud
and we may sort of transition
a workload that we've done.

It's very similar to
other things we've done,
but occasionally, we're hitting something
that we haven't done before.

And so just the ability
to call on our partners

and say, hey, you've
probably seen this before.
We haven't.

Help us understand how
we might navigate this,
and what you've seen work or not work

so that we can try and
avoid those pitfalls.
- Yeah, absolutely.

Definitely having a
strong partner to rely on
gives you a competitive advantage.

And it's very wise to
take advantage of that.
So Brandon, I really wanna thank you
for being with us today.
It was a great conversation.
- Yeah. I enjoyed it.

So it's always exciting to
talk about the transformation.
(upbeat music)
